title: mapping characters
content:
Hi,

I use a certain font for writing musical chord symbols. Now I changed my software for creating sheet music. I would like to keep using my old font with the new software, but unfortunately for transposing, it requires that all twelve pitch names (A, A sharp, B flat etc.) are on certain places in the font. Which of course isn’t the case.

I hoped there would be a way to map the characters in my old font according to the positions in the new font. E.g. a symbol that used to be on Unicode 0021 would have to go to 00A8 etc.

As this is not possible from within the software, can anyone suggest a way to do this outside? It only concerns 5 characters, so it would be ok to spend an hour doing it. However, I wouldn’t want to buy software for this issue...

Thanks a lot.

Peter

comments.content:
If the fonts you’re working with are in TrueType format, and you’re not averse to hand-editing text files (as opposed to working with a GUI), have a look at [TTX](http://web.archive.org/web/20080310054729/http:/www.letterror.com/code/ttx/index.html). It’s free and it will let you do what you’re trying to do.

You can download Windows and Macintosh versions from the <cite>ttx binaries</cite> section on [this page](http://web.archive.org/web/20080310054729/http:/sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=29196).

If you’re using Windows, I compiled a newer version of TTX a while back that you can download from [Adam Twardoch’s TTX page](http://web.archive.org/web/20080310054729/http:/www.font.org/software/ttx/).

Thank you, Spire, it looks like this is the solution to my problem. But unfortunately I can’t quite figure out what to change in all this data.

Can you give me a hint?

Thanks a lot again.

Peter
